div.p: FRIENDSASSOCIATES is one of the 16 major content elements defined as integral to mapping a woman's life in the BIOGRAPHY section of her entry. Because of the ability of our electronic literary history to make links between people, mapping the friendships and personal connections of writers is a very high priority. Systematizing the people that a woman writer knew will allow us to make hitherto unrecognized connections between writers. This original research will provide users with a wealth of information about personal, political, intellectual, and other relationships. To the best of your ability, try to include summary statements about her friendships and associations, paying particular attention to her connections with notable literary and/or historical figures. The title Friendship and Associates is meant to reflect the fact that not all of a woman's associates may be friends. Therefore you may, within this element, discuss enmities, business relations, or associations that are not strictly friendships. It also provides a way to indicate that a woman writer had coffee with Samuel Johnson on one notable day, but that they weren't necessarily friends. Discussions of friendships or relationships that impinged upon the woman's sense of her own sexuality, would be best captured within either Sexuality or INTIMATERELATIONSHIPS. Sometimes, however, the same name needs repeating in both FRIENDSASSOCIATES and INTIMATERELATIONSHIPS. Pay attention to chronology: you may need to open this element several times for different life-stages. To the best of your ability, try to include a CHRONSTRUCT for initial meetings that became central and defining personal friendships. See example below regarding Elizabeth Inchbald's lifelong friendship with Sarah Siddons. This element has one content sub-element, LIVESWITH.

Rebecca West spent summers in the south of France with various friends, including John Van Druten,Beverly Nichols,G. B. Stern, Pamela Frankau and Pat (Wallace) Frere. The friendship between Rebecca West and Pamela Frankau was ruptured when West published a novel denigrating Pamela's loverHumbert Wolfe.

Over her lifetime, Rebecca West made countless friends even in her old age. Her friends included literary colleagues such as Rose Macaulay and DorothyThompson. Other longtime friends included Joyce Seligman and her husband Hugh, and Ruth Lowinsky . Ruth was Rebecca's closest friend for thirty years, and her death in 1958 was a great loss for West.

div.p: All names captured in name tags within a FRIENDSASSOCIATES element are assumed to be either friends or associates of the subject of the biography. In the following example, tag Mary Hays but not Mary Wollstonecraft. She began a correspondence with Mary Hays (friend of fellow Jacobin feminist, Mary Wollstonecraft). Any significant associations with her publishers are not normally to be included under FriendsAssociates. Relations with her publisher are better captured within the Writing section of entries, where you can specify whether the relationship was predominantly personal or professional. Her friendships and connections with other writers should be noted within FRIENDSASSOCIATES. If these relations involved her literary influence on the other writer or the writer's literary or artistic influence on her, discussion of this should be included in her WRITING section.
Question: Charlotte Smith had a longtime relationship with her publisher. Does it go in her Biography section as FRIENDSASSOCIATES?

Answer: This will involve a judgement call concerning the extent of her relationship. Because Smith's connection with her publisher was a significant personal relationship, capture a mention of it under this element in her BIOGRAPHY section, but include the full discussion of the relationship within her WRITING section.
Question: Should friendships with other writers be included under FRIENDSASSOCIATES?
EH was an early correspondent of G. B.Shaw, suggesting to him that he should write plays, while he in turn encouraged her writing.

Answer: This will involve a judgement call. Since the focus of our project is writing, we are emphasizing how these relationships affected her writing more than her life. In most instances where a direct influence is at issue, discussion of the relationship will be captured within her WRITING section. Mention her connection with Shaw in FRIENDSASSOCIATES but include discussion of their mutual influence in her WRITING section.
Question: Should Vera Brittain and Wininfred Holtby's relationship be under FRIENDSASSOCIATES or INTIMATERELATIONSHIPS?
Answer: See INTIMATERELATIONSHIPS. The short answer is some mention in each.
